div.head: A DECLARATION From his Excellencie Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX, and the general Councel of the Armie, held at Putney, Septemb. 9th. 1647.
div.p: WHereas a Member of the General Councel of this Army, hath publickly declared and expressed himself, that there is now no visible Authority in this Kingdom, but the power and force of the Sword: We therefore the said General Councel, to restifie how far our hearts and min des are from any designe of setting up the power of the Sword, above or against the fundamental Authority and Government of the Kingdom, and our readiness to maintain and uphold the same Authority, have by a free Vote in the said Councel, no way contradicting, adjudged the same member to be expelled the Councel, which we hereby thought fit to publish, as a cleer manifestation of our dislike, and disavowing such principles or purposes.

closer.signed: By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the general Councel of the Army. Signed JOHN RUSHWORTH.

div.p: London, Printed for John Pounset, at the signe of the Hand and Bible, at the lower end of Budge row, neer Dowgate. 1674:
A Perfect Diurnall OF SOME PASSAGES IN PARLIAMENT And daily proceedings of the Army under his Excellency Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX.
From Munday the 6 of Sept., till Mund. the 13 of Septemb. 1647.
Collected for the satisfaction of such as desire to be truly informed.
Printed for Francis Coles, and Laurence Blaikelock, and are to be sold at their Shops in the Old-Baily, and at Temple-Barr.

THis Day Mr. Glyn Recorder of London attended the House of Commons according to the Order on Satterday last to answer the charge against him But the House being then very intentive about the busines of sending the propositions to the King, Mr Recorder was put off till the next day.

The debate about, dispatch of the Propositions took up some time, and the Non-concurrence of the Scotch Commissioners some obstruction to the same but it was ordered that the Committee of both Kingdomes should this afternoone desire the Scotch Commissioners positive Answer for that the Houses doe adheare to their former resolutions of sending the Propositions to his Majesty to morrow.

A Report was made to the House and complaint against a dangerous Pamphlet lately printed of one Mr. Iohn Biddles his 12. Arguments upon the Diety, said to be no lesse then Blasphemy denying the third Person, to be God upon debate of this busines It was Ordered the said Pamphlet should be called in, & to be burnt by the hang-man & that the said Mr. Biddle should be referred to the examination of the Committee for plundered M •… sters.

Petition was presented to the Commons from Coli Sanderson on the behalfe of
Capt. Macquire condemned to dy at the Sessions in the Old Baily about the Murther and Ryot at Guild Hall, the Petition was read and some debate, but no Order made upon it.
Petitions on his behalfe were likewise presented to the Generall Sir Thomas Fairfax, his Excelency left it to the pleasure of the houses being no wayes concerned in the businesse.
Much stirring there was in the City on his behalfe, and in fine the Execution (which should have beene this day) was put off, and he likely to gaine the benefit of a Repreive.
An Ordinance this day passed both Houses against Clipped Silver, the businesse so generally concerning the whole Kingdome we will give you the Ordinance.

FOr as much as during these distractions great sums of mony clipped and unlawfully diminished, hane been desperced and given out amongst the people thorowout the Kingdome: for the speede suppression thereof and prevention of the like in the future. Be it ordained by the Lords & Commons in Parl assembled, that from henceforth no mony diminished by clipping or filing shall be currant or payable in this Kingdome, or be offered in payment by any person whatsoever, but to be esteemed as Bullion, and no otherwise, and to the end that such moneys as are by this present Ordieance declared to be uncurrent, may not for the present become unusefull unto such as live in remote parts of the Kingdome and cannot sel them but at under rates. Be it Ordained, That for three Moneths after the date hereof, the said clipt Money shall be allowed of in payment, at foure shillings 10. d. per Ounce for Coldsmiths weighe which is Troy weight, or 4. s. 4. d. halfe-peny the ounce avordupoyz, which is the common weight. And all persons may hereby take notice, that such clipped Money will yeeld in London 4 s. and 11. d. per ounce for Goldsmiths weight, and 4. s. 5. d. halfepeny per ounce for avordupoyz weight at the least. Provided neverthelesse that it is not hereby intended that any old moneys, which are apparent not to be clipt, or otherwise unlawfully diminished, but onely growne light through wearing and wasting, by long passing from hand to hand shall be included within this Order, but shall still be •… nt without disput •… s formerly.

closer.signed: Jo. Br • wn Cler, Parl D. com.

div.p: An Ordinance for making Col. Hamond Governour of the Isle of Wight was againe read and passed the Commons.

Letters likewise were presented to the house comming from the Lord Inchiquin, desiring monyes, &c. These with some other letters concerning the same businesse were referred to the Committee of both Kingdomes.

The letters from Ireland give to understand that the Officers and Souldiers with the Lord Inchiquin have been upon, dangerous designes lately, and in particular upon a Remonstrance or Declaration resenting the proceedings of Parliament and Army in England, the pretence being want of pay, discharge from service and the like, yet that it might not be thought they intended to countenance or accommodate the Rebells, Its declared that they resolve to goe on against them vigorously, but withall declare that they will not admit of any alteration in government Mat •… iall, till their Arrears be paid them both whats due in England and Ireland &c.
The Commons passed a Declaration for disableing all delinquents that have borne arms against the Parliament to be any publique officers in the Kingdome and the Lords concurrence desired.

From Newcastle Sept. the second tis certified that the Generall assembly have not yet published their declaration in Scotland. The committee of Estates in expectation of the Messenger who was sent to London, and to the Generall for passes for the Lords, the Messenger passed here this night with passes for them.

Six or 8000 of the Scot • sh forces it is certified are drawing southwards and intend to Quarter on the confines of Scotland, but it is [they say] onely for better accommodation and benifit of fresh Quarter.

REport was this day made to the House of the concurrence of the Scotch Commissioners to the Propositions for Peace, whereupon a Letter was agreed upon to the Commissioners with the King, and Instructions from the Houses to present the Propositions to his Majesty and to receive his answer within six dayes To which Letter and instructions both houses concurring the said propositions were sent away this afternoone to his Majesty at Hampton-Covrt the Commissioners who are to present the same are these as following The Eark of Pembrook, the Lord Montague, Sir Iames Harrington, sir Iohn Cook, sir Iohn Holland, Major Generall Brown, (commissioners from both Houses of the Parliament of England and the Earl of Loutherdale and sir Charles Erskin and two other commissioners from the Kingdome of Scotland.

A Letter this day passed both houses to be sent to the Estates of Scotland for the reca • ling of the Scottish Forces out of Vlster in Ireland according to the first agreement and treaty for Ireland there being in furth • r need to continue those forces in that Kingdome, the Houses resolving to prosecure that war in Ireland with the forces of this Kingdome only.
Master Rowe a Gentleman that hath deserved well of this Kingdom for his former service was appointed to goe with the Letter into Scotland.
An Order was brought downe by Message to the Commons of directions to the M • litia of London about slighting the Workes and Lines of Communication.
Vpon the petition of Colonell Baynes prisoner in Woodstreet Counter that the said prison was infected with the plague, it was ordered that he should be removed to Peter House.
The House of Peeres had before them the Ordinance in behalf of the Officers of the Court of Wards and committed the same.

Mr. Glyn the Recorder this day againe attended the Commons and the House then proceeded upon the Informations and proofes against him. which were read and in summe were, That he had been very active in the actions in London for a new war. Countenanced the cities last declaration
Encouraged the Ryotus petitioners, had been very active with the Committee of safety and new Committee of the Militia of London &c.

And Mr. Glynn being called into the house had the particulars of his Charge laid open to him, to which he made a large defence in a very well composed, and advised speech to the house, and afterwards with drawing the House debated the matter very consideratly, and in fine the Question being put, the house was devided, but it was carried in the affirmative, That Mr, Glynn Recorder of London should be discharged from being any longer a Member of the Commons house.
And that further he should be committed to the tower there to remaine during pleasure of the house.
And much time being spent about this busines, it was ordered that he should be brought before the house to receive his sentence to morrow morning.

The Commons then proceeded to the case of Sir Iohn Maynard appointed also to attend this day, & upon hearing of the charge against him with proofe upon oath, that he had with great zeale and activity endeavoured the raising of a new Warr, and in prosecution thereof had subscribed Warrants for the raising of Horse within the City, &c.

Sir Iohn was called into the house; had liberty to speak what he could in his defence, and afterwards withdrawing, It was voted, that he should be discharged from being any longer a Member of that house, that he should be committed prisoner to the tower, and that an impeachment of high treason should be drawne up against him.
The Commons ordered that Lieutenant Col. Lilburnes case prison the Tower should be reported to morrow.
Ordered further that the Report concerning the prisoners in the Tower be made.

This day at a common councell in London a letter was read and debated from his Dxcellency Sir Tho, Fairfax which they received the night before with direction to the Lord mayor, aldermen and common councell, and it was as followeth.

p.hi:
BEing informed that the City of London is in Arredre to the Army a very greate summe. and understanding that care is taken by the Committee of Parliament for the army to provide money seasonably for the payment thereof, by sending to you to advance Fifty thousand pounds upon the security of what is due from you which is a far greater summe then is desired to be presently advanced by you although we can not conceive that there will be any backwardnesse in you to answer this desire which is so reasonable, and of such necessity to the satisfaction and well ordering of the Army, Yet we thought good to write unto you about it, that so you may understand so much from us, with this, that Delay Will be equall to a deny all and cause us to think that little regard
is had of us, or the endeavours now in hand tending to the Settlement of the peace of the Kingdome, which is so much desired and hoped for by us and all honest men, and to the obtaining of which timely supplyes of money and especially the present payment of the summe above-named will very much induce.

closer.signed: By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Tho. Fairfax and councell of War signed, Io. Rushworth.

postscript.p: POSTSCRIPT, We understand it's neere a fortnight since the Committee applyed themselves to you in this businesse, and that yet nothing is done, we desire there may be a present performance, the condition of the army not admitting any longer delay:

div.p: THe Commons this day further proceeded in the Report from the committee how farr any Members of Parliament had been active in the late design of a new War, and Tumults in London, and they had before them the cases of severall Lords Members of the House of Peeres and upon dedebate of the informations and proofes against them, The Commons voted an Impeachment of high treason against them vizt. against Iames Earle of Suffolk, Francis Lord Willioughby of Parham, Iohn Lord Hunsden, William Lord Maynard, Theobald Earle of Lincoln George Lord Berkley and Iames Earl of Middlesex for levying of Warre against the King, Parliament, and Kingdom.

And the commons sent a Message to the House of peers to Impeach the said Lords of High Treason at the Bar of that house & to desire their Lordships that they may be sequestered from the service of the house & committed to custody, and that the commons would be ready when their Lordships should please to bring a particuler Charge against them which was don accordingly.

Their Lordshipps taking into debate the said charge appointed to meet in full House about the same to morrow, and that the said Impeached Lords should have notice to attend, which was also done accordingly.

The case of another Peere should have been reported but upon some consideration was put off for a weeks times. Sir Iohn Maynard was carried prisoner to the Tower according to the Order yesterday, and Mr. Recorder received his sentance in the Commons house but it was ordered that his committment to the Tower should be dispensed withall for a week that he may have time to sore and deliver up his papers and writings in relation to his place of Recorder of London, or to his clyents at Law, and to remain in custody.
The Commmons had then further debate and ordered that the case of Commissary Copely a Member of the House should be reported to morrow and hee Ordered to attend the House?

It was also Ordered that the case of Sir Robert Harlow Mr. Edward Stephens and Mr. Guen Members of the House should be reported to the House on Tuesday next and they ordered to attend the House at that time.
The Lords sent a Message to the Commons about the Ordinance for taking of the sequestration of the Duke of Buckingham.
Also Recomending a petition of the Lady Grays to the Commons.

One of the Kings land water place of the custome house being void, great striving was for obtaining the same and it was by Order of the House this day bestowed upon one of note and desert in the City.

This day Master Biddles Booke against the Diety of the 3 person in trenity was burned according to the Order of parliament. Master Lilburns case by reason of the former businesses was put of til an other day.

From Hampton court it is certified that the commissioners delivered the propositions for peace to his Majesty the last night there happened little in Exchange betwixt his Majesty and the commissionours at the deliv • ry only his Majesty tould them he would returne answer with all conveniency.

Letters from Ireland give further to understand that the proceedings upon the declaration or remonstrance by the Lord inchiq •… es offi • es is in a good way stopped, and likely to proceede no further but the Soul, dies cry out much for monies.

From Dublin they writ that the partie sent out by Colonell Iones into the Co • nty of Wickley are returned with a prize of 7 or 8000 Cowes and have burnt downe greatest part of the Towne of Wickloe In this expedition they met with noe Enimy, that party of prestons that escaped in the last fight never rallying nor its likely will not get to any considerable Head until the next Spring.

THis day the Commons passed an Ordinance to which also the Lords concurred for constituting a Committee of Militia for the City of Westminster and the other out parishes not within the Walls of London, Savoy parish, Clements Danes, Giles in the Fields, •… drewes Holborne, Sepulchers, Iames Clerkenwed, Mary Iflington, and Giles Creplegate in the county of Middlesex, with power to the commit • ee to arme, Trayne, and D • scipline all persons fit for service, and to appoint colonells, captaines and other Officers, and in all points having a full power as the committee for the Militia of London; which Ordinance is to continue during the pleasure of the houses, the names of the committe for this Militia are as followeth, viz Sir Gregory Norton Kt. Humphrey Edward, Io Trenchard, Cornelius Holland
and Iohn Browne Clerk of the Parliament, William Ball, Richard Keble, George Manley, Iosias Berners, Richard Graves, Nicholas Martin, Iohn Hall, Iohn Heyl •… , and Edward Denby Iunior, Esquires William Parker Dr. in Physick, Iames Prince, Silvanus Taylor, Georg Crompton, Iohn Ro •… son, Noah Banks, Peter Lindsey, Richard Big, Ralph Farmer, Nicholas Bond; Arthar Squib, Iohn Honnor, Richard Bates, Samuel Smith, Iohn Clendon, Francis Blake, Ralph Grey, Iohn Frampton, Edward Neal William Stone, and Wether Frost, or any seaven or more of them.
An other Ordinance likewise passed for constituting the like committee with the same power as the former for the Borrough of Southwark.

And an other Ordinance for the Tower Hamblets, and that the Trained Bands and auxiliaries of the Tower be under the immediate command of the constable of of the Tower as they were before under the command of the Militia.

An Ordinance likewise passed the houses for enabling the Militia of London, Westminster, &c to pull downe the courts of Guard and Lines of communication and to make sale of the Timber for defraying necessary charges for pulling downe of the same.

Likewise a further order past for inviting the Inhabitants of London and Westminster to send their Servants to help to pull downe the Forts and Line about the city, and to desire them to begin this worke munday morning next.

There was a Petition this day presented to the Commons and read from the common councell of London, and it was by way of answer to the desire of both houses for the borrowing the summe of 50000 l. of the city for the supply of the army, giving reasons wherefore they could not at this time advance the said summe as desired having likewise the day before returned the like answer to the Generalls Letter.

The house debated the businesse, but considering how great the necessities of the army is, at present for want of monyes, Ordered that the city should be further desired to advance that summe by Saterday come sev • night, the necessities of the army nor admitting any longer delay.
The Lords sent a Message to the recommending the condition of the Earle of Portland.
There Lordships also concurred with the Commons in the Ordinance for continuing the Major of Worcester in his place so some rime longer.

The busines of Commisary Copely was reported to the House, and took up much time in debate the proofes were of his Joyning with the Committee for raising of forces for a new Warre and his complyance with the proceedings of the Members in the Speakers absence and at last It was put to the vote and voted that he should be discharged the service of the House and committed to the Tower during pleasure
The house had also debate concerning Captaine Musgrave taken into custody the day befor as a great stickler in the late busines of the City, and it was ordered he should be sent prisonour to Newgate.

The house of Peers this day (as was ordered) debated the businesse and impeachment of their Members in a full house, and it was voted and Ordered that the Gentleman Vsher of their house, seize, and bring before their Lordships, the said Earle of Lincolne, Earle of Suffolk, and Earl of Middlesex: The Lord Hunsdon, Lord Willoughby of Parham Lord Bartlet, and Lord Maynard, to answer the Impeachment of high Treason brought up against them by the House of Commons.

THis day was published an Declaration passed Both houses yesterday that none shall be elected into any Office whatsoever, that hath been in the Kings Army ayding or assisting the enimy against the parliament, within the Kingdom of England, dominion of Wales, and Towne of Barwick. The declaration is as followeth.

BE it Declared, Ordered and ordained by the Lords and Commons in Parliament assembled, That no Person whatsoever, that hath been in Armes against the Parliament, or hath been aiding or assisting the Forces of the Enemy, or hath been, or is sequestred, shall be elected, or constituted Mayor, Alderman, Bailiffe, Sheriffe, Iustice of Peace Steward of any Court, Constable, or any other Officer in any County, City, Borough, or Towne corporate, within the Kingdome of England, Dominion of Wales, and Towne of Berwick; And in case any such Persons as aforesaid he elected into any of the Offices aforesaid, in any of the aforesaid places: the Lords and Commons doe declare all such elections to be void and null, Provided that this shall not extend to any person or persons who have been, or shall be unduely sequestered as delinquents, and have been or shall be therefore discharged of the said undue Sequestration, by both houses of Parliament or by the Lords and Commons for Sequestration.

From Scotland it is further confirmed by letters That David Lesley with the Scots army which are come over Spey, are most of them appointed to quarter on the parts of Scotland, bordering upon England: The Lord Chancelour, and Lord Lanrick, are ready to come for England and have received their instructions, they are to presse for monyes and assistance for securing Scotland, and for uniformity in Religion acording to the covenant. They bring also a Declaration with them from the Estates, wherein many things are in relation to the Covenant, and the Treaty.
Satterday produced little, the Houses not sitting they having adjourned untill tuesday next.

From Putney the Head-quarters of the Army we understand that the councell of war and Commissioners of Parliament sit daily about disband •… , putting into Garrisons, disposing of the Horse, and the busines of Ireland, which would be sone perfected if moneys, could be raised; But that no moneyes for pay of the Army should be sent them in all this time much discontents the Souldery.

From our Commissioners who presented the Propositions to the King at Hampton Court came letters which tell that his Majesty is preparing an Answer to send to the Houses, and hath already in effect declared his sence of the Propositions, That to severall of the Propositions he is willing to assent, settle Presbitry in this Kingdome for three yeares, The M • litia as he before offered, &c. But others he is no wayes satisfied in or can assent unto, but desires to put him selfe upon the Proposalls of the Army, and that they may be taken into consideration by the Houses.
